text: English grammar lesson 19 topic
pronunciation patterns of phrasal verbs
watch and listen can you identify three
phrasal verbs
today I drove up to New Hampshire to get
my accordion tuned at accordion
connection I ended up doing more repairs
than I expected but my accordion is in
good condition now so I'll Drive back
happy
you heard these three phrasal verbs
drive up end up drive back remember a
phrasal verb is a verb plus one or more
particles when these parts come together
they create a new definition did you
understand the meanings of these three
phrasal verbs I said I drove up to New
Hampshire my home is in Massachusetts
and New Hampshire is in the north to
drive up means to go north by car I also
said I ended up doing more repairs than
I expected so if you end up doing
something you find yourself in an
unexpected situation finally I drove
back from New Hampshire I returned to
drive back is to return by car note how
we can easily create new phrasal verbs
if we change our mode of transportation
for example if I go by plane I can fly
up fly back if I go by ship
I can sail up sail back all right now
that we remember what phrasal verbs are
let's recall more about their structure
phrasal verbs can be either transitive
or intransitive if they're intransitive
they do not take an object if they're
transitive they do take an object
transitive phrasal verbs can be either
separable or inseparable if you need a
review of the structure of phrasal verbs
please go back to lesson 18 it's helpful
to keep the structure in mind so that
you better understand the pronunciation
patterns these verbs follow the main
question we need to answer in this
lesson is which part or parts of a
phrasal verb do we stress the key word
in the term phrasal verb is phrase so
we're going to focus on stressed words
within a phrase sometimes the verb will
receive the stress sometimes the
particle will receive the stress and
other times both the verb and the part
Nicole will be stressed I'm going to
teach you three basic patterns let's
begin with the first watch and listen as
you can see I'm home now so if you'd
like I can show you my accordion not
easy to pick an accordion of accordions
are heavy instruments I bought this one
just a few weeks ago it's not new
I bought it secondhand which means it
was owned by somebody else which also
means I didn't have to spend too much
money so this is my accordion I like it
but when I bought it there were two
things wrong one it was a little out of
tune and two on the back someone had put
tape here I don't know why I couldn't
figure that out why do you need tape on
an instrument so I decided to take the
tape off
listen closely again it's not easy to
pick an accordion up I couldn't figure
that out I decided to take the tape off
which words were stressed both the verb
and the particle we have three
transitive phrasal verbs and they are
separable if you look at the sentences
an object separates the particle from
the verb so what is the pattern stress
both the verb and the particle when an
object separates them if there is more
than one particle stress the verb and
the first particle I want to note that
while both the verb and the particle are
stressed the particle tends to receive
slightly more stress as in figure that
out take the tape off do you hear how
the particle is slightly more stressed
all right let's move on to the second
pattern watch and listen once the tape
was taken off I was left with these very
ugly tape marks and unfortunately these
tape marks don't wash off that's one
reason why I decided to buy this pad now
I can't see the tape marks more
important the pad makes it very
comfortable for me when I play
listen closely again once the tape was
taken off I was left with these very
ugly tape marks unfortunately these tape
marks don't wash off which words were
stressed only the particle in the first
sentence takeoff is a transitive phrasal
verb but it's being used in the passive
voice so there is no object in the
second sentence wash off is an
intransitive phrasal verb again we have
no object so what's the second pattern
stress the particle of a phrasal verb
when it comes at the end of a sentence
or phrase in other words before a pause
let's move on to the third pattern watch
and listen

let's summarize what we've just learned
pattern 1 stress both the verb and the
particle when an object separates them
example take the tape off with the
particle receiving slightly more stress
pattern to stress the particle of a
phrasal verb when it comes at the end of
a sentence or phrase in other words
before a pause example it doesn't wash
off pattern 3 stress either the main
verb or the particle when it's followed
by an object let the rhythm of the
sentence guide you here's an example
using pick up in two different sentences
I can't pick up the accordion can you
please pick up my accordion exercise one
read each statement aloud decide which
stress pattern is appropriate for the
phrasal verb example look at the
statement think what kind of phrasal

there's no object this phrasal verb has
no object and it falls at the end of a
phrase before pause what does that mean
we should stress the particle the rhythm
is it's easier if I sit down to play
it's easier if I sit down to play one
read the statement which parts of the

the rhythm is I'm not going to ask that
you put up with my bed playing for more

playing for more than one song
to read the statement which parts of the

according to the basic patterns we
should stress the particle but this
phrasal verb doesn't fall at the end of
a phrase or the end of a sentence it
doesn't come before pause we have this
IMG form of the verb keep on playing
so I think we should let the overall

after all we're dealing with patterns

I think the overall rhythm is telling us

of the verb playing let me clap the

keep on playing I'll just keep on
playing other intransitive phrasal verbs
followed by the ing form of the verb
include end up and go on as in end up

the rhythm is hopefully you won't turn

hopefully you won't turn off your
